thread.title: Alexandria chef to take on Austin restaurant scene
thread.title_full: Alexandria chef to take on Austin restaurant scene

title: Alexandria chef to take on Austin restaurant scene
text:
Alexandria chef to take on Austin restaurant scene Michele Marcotte, mmarcotte@gannett.com 6:03 a.m. CDT October 9, 2015 Louisiana Culinary Trails and Texas Monthly partner to bring chefs from both states together in Austin. Scroll to the bottom to find out more on each of the nine chefs. Louisiana dishes will be featured at select Austin restaurants Tuesday as part of the Louisiana Lone Star Restaurant Night. (Photo: Courtesy of Louisiana Culinary Trails) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Louisiana is about to spice up Austin's restaurant scene. 
On Tuesday,nine Louisiana chefs — Stephen Naegle Jr., of Spirits Food & Friends — will bring the state’s world-class cuisine to several Austin restaurants for the Louisiana-Lone Star Restaurant Night. The culinary event is a partnership between The Louisiana Travel Promotion Association, its local partners, the Louisiana Office of Tourism, and Texas Monthly. 
"It gives people there a chance to eat outside of their box," Naegle said. "If you're from Alabama, Texas, Mississippi or Florida, you have certain things you eat on a regular basis ... This makes you go outside that box." 
Naegle is eager to demonstrate what makes his region's cuisine special. 
Central Louisiana has experienced a "green movement" over the past few years, and Naegle said he is excited to show Austin the healthier side of Louisiana cuisine. 
Stephen Naegle, Spirits Food & Friends, Alexandria. Naegle is one of nine Louisiana chefs participating in Tuesday's Louisiana Lone Star Restaurant Night in Austin. (Photo: Melinda Martinez/mmartinez@thetowntalk.com) 
His collaboration with Cover 3 Chef Kirk Doyle will feature a mixed green salad with a Cane herb vinaigrette, a roasted corn bisque with jumbo lump crabmeat and Kirk’s bacon jam. It also will feature a cast iron redfish with andouille sausage coarse grits and crispy softshell crawfish and colossal shrimp with a sherry shallot aioli. 
In addition to Naigle, participating Louisiana chefs include: Ryan Andre, City Pork , Baton Rouge 
“In Louisiana, we have a great love for distinct flavors and delicious cuisine,” said Kyle Edmiston, assistant secretary, Louisiana Office of Tourism in a news release. “We know Texans share this passion for food and we’re excited to showcase what chefs from destinations all throughout Louisiana are doing.” 
Convention and tourist bureaus across the state selected Louisiana chefs with cuisine indicative of their region. They tasked each with showcasing distinctively Louisiana dishes to be featured at select Austin restaurants. Reservations can be made at texasmonthly.com/promotion/louisianalonestar. 
Similar to Naigle, Girouard looks forward to representing his city and sharing Lafayette’s unique cuisine with the Lone Star State. 
RELATED: How Cenla cuisine differs from the rest of the state 
He will cook specials at central Austin's Hillside Farmacy on Tuesday. Girouard hopes those will include popular menu items— such as the sweet baby breesus and Cajun eggs benedict — from his downtown Lafayette restaurant. The menu has not been finalized. 
"These are two different dishes to show how boudin can be used in different ways with different flavors," he said. 
He isn't the only one interested in showcasing regional Louisiana foods. 
Shreveport's Anthony Felan plans to showcase Ruston peaches in the dessert portion of his three-course menu at Austin's The Carillon. 
The dish is a buttermilk custard with peach gelee, cane vinegar soaked peach, bourbon gastrique, graham cracker dust, mint, basil cream and carbonated sugar. It's the end to a special that starts with a cold smoked Gulf Coast yellow tail crudo and offers a chicken fried bacon wrapped rabbit porchetta with red bean cassoulet as the main course. 
"We're using Louisiana ingredients and doing a modern twist on our food," he said. 
The red bean cassoulet, for instance, is a play on the Louisiana staple red beans and rice, Felan said. 
Nine Louisiana chefs are joining forces with select Austin restaurant for the Louisiana Lone Star Restaurant Night on Tuesday. The dinner is a collaboration between Louisiana Culinary Trails and Texas Monthly. (Photo: Courtesy of Louisiana Culinary Trails) 
Louisiana chefs were paired with Texas chefs with similar cooking styles, said Laura Cating, a spokeswoman for the Louisiana Travel Promotion Association. 
Monroe's Blake Phillips can see the similarities between himself and Fixe's James Robert. 
"He is actually from Louisiana , as well, and I think our upbringing was similar," Phillips said, adding both he and Robert offer creative twists on Southern classics. 
Phillips' three-course special at Fixe will showcase that. The first course is a pork belly with crispy Gulf Coast oysters with corn chow-chow and dijon bechamel (a creamy mustard sauce). The second course is Gulf snapper with New Orleans-style barbecue rock shrimp and hearty vegetables. The final course is a pecan pie with dark chocolate napoleon with burnt honey ice cream. 
He is as eager to collaborate in kitchen as share Louisiana flavors with Texas diners. 
"Just to be part of another chef's atmosphere is great," he said. "We can learn from how we do things differently, and I can try to take away something from it that I can bring back (to Louisiana)." Read or Share this story: http://www.thetowntalk.com/story/entertainment/2015/10/09/alexandria-chef-take-austin-restaurant-scene/73631528/ More Stories Oct. 7, 2015, 11:14 p.m. Louisiana Lone Star Restaurant Night Chefs Meet the nine Louisiana chefs participating in the Louisiana Lone Star Restaurant Night. Sponsored by Alexandria Stephen Naegle Jr., Spirits Food & Friends 
Born and raised in Colombia, Naegle's love for cooking led him to Mexico City and Florida before planting his roots in Alexandria and creating dishes that fuse his colorful culinary history with the familiar tastes that his area loves. Chef Kirk Doyle will host Chef Naegle at Cover 3-Downtown, located at 1717 W. 6th St. #210R in Austin. Baton Rouge Ryan Andre, City Pork 
Andre keeps it local in his hometown by using fresh Louisiana seafood and wild game including fish, oysters, shrimp, duck and rabbit. He incorporates the state's rich European fare with a heavy dose of Asian influence to offer visitors a taste of the international flavors of Baton Rouge. Chef Carlos Ysaguiree will host Chef Andre at Jacoby's Restaurant & Mercantile, located at 3235 E. Cesar Chavez St. Covington Jeffrey Hansell, Oxlot 9 
In an area well known for fresh produce and Louisiana seafood, Hansell brings upscale, gulf-inspired southern fare to quaint downtown Covington at the restored Southern Hotel. Chef Andrew Curren will host Chef Hansell at Arro, located at 601 W. Sixth St. New Orleans John Martin, Tableau 
With a restaurant in New Orleans' picturesque Jackson Square, Martin offers diners classic French Creole dishes that are sophisticated, yet true to tradition, with great depth of flavor. Chef Janina O'Leary will host Chef Martin at LaV Restaurant & Wine Bar, located at 1501 E. 7 th St. Lafayette Justin Girouard, The French Press, 
Located in the heart of Cajun country, Girouard puts his own distinctive spin on classic dishes - such as his Cajun Benedict, which uses French bread instead of English muffins, boudin instead of Canadian bacon and is topped with chicken and andouille gumbo instead of hollandaise. Chef Sonya Cote will host Chef Girouard at Hillside Farmacy, located at 1209 East 11 th St. Lake Charles Brett Baldwin, Landry's Seafood House at Golden Nugget 
Baldwin enjoys bringing his native-Louisiana roots to his cooking, including his favorite dish to prepare-blackened catfish served over a bed of dirty rice, topped with lemon butter, capers and crawfish, and accompanied by Creole green beans. Chef Nathan Lemley will host Chef Baldwin at Parkside, located at 301 E. 6 th St. Lake Charles Lyle Broussard, Jack Daniel's® Bar & Grill at L'Auberge Casino Resort Broussard is known for his Cajun and creole flavors and his passion for southwest Louisiana culture and cuisine. Chef Broussard's love of his local heritage carries over to the menu with authenticity, deep flavors and a simplicity that allows the ingredients to do the talking. Chef Neil Joiner and Chef Joseph Bixel will host Chef Broussard at Porter Ale House & Gastropub, located at 3715 S. 1 st St., Suite A Shreveport Anthony Felan, Wine Country Bistro & Bottle Shop 
Felan is an active leader in the farm-to-table movement and has focused on using local, seasonal ingredients in his menu. Chef Christopher Wilson will host Chef Felan at The Carillon, located at 1900 University Ave. Monroe Blake Phillips, Restaurant Sage 
A native of Monroe, Phillips actually attended culinary school in Austin, and then spent seven years cooking in some of the most famous kitchens in New Orleans. From globally inspired dishes to creative, southern cuisine, he now works passionately to please every palette at his Monroe restaurant. Chef James Roberts will host Chef Phillips at FIXE, located 500 West 5 th St. Louisiana Culinary Travels
